One of Cape Town's best museums. The story of the Jews in South Africa is brilliantly portrayed in this elegant museum in the heart of the city. The quality of the exhibits and the multi-media presentations put this right up there as a tribute to a vital segment of South African history. Parking in the street nearby.

Wish we had more time. So handy for the Hop-On Hop-Off bus. Glad we brought some proper ID for security entry to site.The staff were friendly and helpful. Had no idea there was such a connection with Mandela. The Holocaust display was deeply moving.There is a small cafe restaurant onsite.

Interesting.. The museum is located in a beautiful, quiet neighborhood. We enjoyed our personal tour from the woman at the welcome desk. She was very patient and talked about the temple and allowed photos to be taken. Very informal but informative. Across the walkway was an additional museum that was self guided and interesting.
Jewish Museum worth a visit. Interesting and informative and not only about the Jewish community. Gives history of South Africa in general and through the eyes of the immigrant Jewish population.

Very moving and great contribution of great community.. What an amazing community the two parts show the great contribution of this wonderful community.The Holocaust part is very moving and a must see by all people.

Holacaust museum. Visited both Jewish and holacaust museum. The holacasut museum was very moving and informative. It is hard to believe that mankind could treat another human being in such an appalling way. The cafe was a lovely place to visit

A worthwhile visit. The Jewish Museum is part of a complex which includes the hold and new synagogues as well as the Holocaust Museum. All are worth seeing. The history of the Jewish community in Cape Town is quite interesting, and the synagogue is lovely. The Holocaust Museum was the most engaging. There are models of a shtetl in Lithuania (from whence a large part of the SA Jewish community emigrated) which tugged at our heartstrings. At the end of the visit the videos of Holocaust survivors who ended up in South Africa was highly emotional and heartwarming.

A slice of South African history. This was a repeat visit after an absence of several years, so the changes were interesting. The building has been modernised and the exhibitions are more high-tech. Except the little Lithuanian model village, which still creates the same impression of being the abode of a poor but proud people.And clean and neat! There is not a scroll out of place and the examples on exhibit were (for non-Jews) very good examples of what sustained the Jews throughout the Diaspora. And the nice link with the Jewish settlers in South Africa is still there from Cape Town to the Gold Fields.The old 'smouskar' of bygone years is still on view, but unfortunately now it is roped off and one can but gaze at it from behind a barrier instead of inspecting it and the goods that were carried in it close-up.Even the coffee shop outside is a nice touch. Clean and neat, it gives an opportunity to reflect in quiet contemplation. And the guard at the gate (sadly, a modern-day necessity) was friendly yet firm in carrying out his duties. There is still construction work going on and one can but hope that space will be made to exhibit Jewish life in SA in more modern times, not so much in political terms as in the contributions that ordinary people continue to make to add to their forebears' contributions to building a prosperous South Africa.Well worth a visit even if you're not Jewish.

One of the best and most interesting in the world. We have been to a fair share of Jewish museums around the world and this one really sticks out. It was openend by Nelson Mandela. It starts in the first synagogue in South-Africa with the history of the Jewish Community in Cape Town and South-Africa and even has some models of synagogues around South-Africa. Then it moves on to describe the contribution the Jewish people played during the days of Apartheid. Finishing off with famous Jews.Next door is the current synagogue which holds about 1400 people and is really worth the visit. Not just beautiful from the outside, but also stunning from the inside. It reminds me of the portugese synagogue in Amsterdam in some aspects.In the final building there is a coffee shop and a little gift shop, but there is also a holocaust exhibition and a documentary about Nelson Mandela. You can truly spend hours here and the way everything is displayed and made interactive should be an example to other similar museums around the world.

very interesting. we found it very interesting to learn about the Jewish community in Cape Town and South Africa , how they came to be and when . Part of the Museum is about the Apartheid and how the Jewish community reacted to it as well as about the Holocaust. Very very interesting.
A well thought out museum. Informative and extremely well prepared layout which all visitors should plan on their itinerary of Cape Town
Jewish Museum. We enjoyed talking to the guide and sharing stories about holiday celebrations in the US. We also were touched by the Holocaust Museum.
history. this museum gives a strong sense of history unknown to a lot of people and is a visit to understand the great sense of what a nation feels

Beautiful museum and grounds. Centrally located museum about the Jewish community in South Africa, in addition to a Holocaust Museum. Needless to say, the Holocaust Museum is a moving one that reminds us of the tragedy that unfolded not too many years ago. It is a smaller one than the Washington's Holocaust museum, but certainly brings home the message equally as well. The grounds are a pleasure to spend time in, along with a small cafe for lunch. Staff very helpful and welcoming.

fascinating , must-see in combination with the holocaust museum. A definite must-see! The Jewish Museum is gorgeous and the holocaust adjacent to it is a compilation of stark photographs that should be seen and considered.

How Jewish people and their faith influenced South African history. We visited for the second time. As a Christian, the Jewish heritage interests me greatly as it is where my faith originated. I love how the first synagogue in South Africa has been kept intact and each symbol of the faith has been restored and explained. The "boat" showing the immigrants into Cape Town is well done as are the shtetls, which my children enjoyed. The extra touches of traditional music in each display is lovely. I disagree with the above review as I found that Jewish rituals and practices are shown well as are the Jewish influences into South Africa's history, especially during the awful time of apartheid. (A tolerant nation that seems to get very little tolerance in return.)

An interesting museum. I liked the South African Jewish Museum. They explained the reason, why the Baltic Jews came to South Africa. The exhibition downstairs about the Baltic shtetls was nicely displayed.
A must, also Holocaust Museum. Beautifully set out and details the history of the Jews in the Cape. My regret was that there was not more on the rest of the area.

A must to see. So well set out and a Guide answered all the questions we asked about Jewish customs.
A lovely experience.

Moving and interesting. Don't miss this museum which tells the history of Jewish settlement and influence in South Africa and also much about the holocaust. There is also a chance to see the inside of a synagogue, if services are not being held there. Some wonderful works of art on display when we were there.
Interesting, educational, moving. Definitely worth a visit, long or short, and easily done via hop-on hop-off bus or if in the viscinity.

Fascinating. A very modern and beautifully designed museum. A fascinating insight into the contribution of the Jewish people to the development of South Africa and resistance to apartheid. There is also a harrowing section on the holocaust.

Africa's Jewish History. Opened by Nelson Mandela himself, the S.A. Jewish Museum chronicles the country's long and storied Jewish history. From the early mercantile pioneers to the refugees from the pogroms of Eastern Europe to those who locked arms with Mandela to oppose apartheid, the museum takes a rich and detailed look at those Jews who are an integral part of the country. During our visit, a group of students from a Muslim school were listening raptly to a docent lecture about anti-Semitism. Both inspiring and humbling, a rewarding experience for travelers of any (or no) religion.

Fascinating glimpse at Jewry in SA. If you are interested in history and have an afternoon in Cape Town then this is a fantastic museum to visit. They often have special exhibitions and the Holocaust Centre is a critical education resource in the Western Cape. If you are visiting Cape Town during the rainy winter months and need an attraction out of the weather with good coffee this makes a great addition to any itinerary.

Very impressive museum. Heart wrenching. Extremely well done and large collection of Holocaust memorabilia with pictures and stories that are all heart wrenching. The horrors and the stories of such strength. Well worth seeing and experiencing. Beautiful location in a former synagogue.

Unexpected surprise. Usually a museum devoted to one corner of society would be for me a turn off.But this excellent museum with its insights into the Jewish South African population is a must.A tiny Synagogue sits in the heart of the exhibition as well as a reproduction of an of an ol Jewish village.There is also a collection of Japanese Netsuke.

Small, beautiful and touching. Compact setting in old synagogue with modern extension. Varied exhibits, well laid out, nice mix of original artefacts and records with modern audiovisuals a recreated shetl. Should be of interest to all with an interest in history and culture. Own secure parking. Cafe on location, and easy access to other museums, company gardens, etc.

Unique. This is a very good overview of the Jewish experience in South Africa, and well worth visiting. The displays are clearly laid out, and chronologically make sense. There was a special art display when I was there that was excellent.

Wonderful experience. Having experienced your Friday evening service, which was spectacular with the visiting choir from Linksfield (J'Burg), we visited the S.A. Jewish Museum and had a professional and excellent guide, Brian K. The information and empathy was outstanding, Brian gave a lot of information without overdoing it as everyone in the group had a good background to Judaism and some advance info from our tour in Johannesburg. Keep up your excellent PR, thanks for a memorable visit.Evelyn Plotke and the La Bimba Group, Switzerland

Well laid out. One of the best Jewish museums that we've been to, detailing the history of the Jewish settlers mainly from Lithuania. There is a kosher coffee shop and bookshop, that had some nice things that weren't over expensive.
worth the detour. great guide who explained the history of the Jews in CT. The synagogue is beautiful, good museum shop.

An emotional tour de force. We were using the hop on off bus tour and this was one of the stops.We were a wee bit surprised to find we needed to show passports or photo id to enter but the security guys were very polite and we guess in this day and age they have to be careful as we were generally in our travels in South Africa.It was very interesting to find that school 6th forms have the Holocaust on their curriculum and we met one of the school groups en tour.We took advantage of having a guide take us round and explain everything.This was a very moving and an eye opener for seeing just what horrors had transpired.After spending time on the tour and then visiting the museum we stopped for a bite in the on site restaurant. The food was great and everybody we met was so friendly.We are really glad we made time for this visit.

Good overview of Jewish migration from Europe. Apart from the obligatory ephemera of Jewish life and worship, this museum has constructed a replica of an Eastern European village (reminiscent of Fiddler on the Roof). It's quite well done, and the exhibits and notice boards put the story into context. The Synagogue is attractive and is also worth a visit.

Be sure to have photo ID with you - or you wont get in. If you have time, have the guide take you around. We didn't and found ourselves skimming around the museum not really taking much in. The art gallery was good and the Japanese collection was lovely. The Holocaust displays were as moving as you would expect and we came away with a very good impression of the whole experience.

A must for visitors to Cape Town interested in its history. We visited the museum because we are Jewish but feel that this would be interesting for none Jews as their is a link to Apartheid and the Holocaust. It's also interesting to see how much of the development of South Africa was influenced by the Jewish settlers. For anyone that has read The Hare with Amber Eyes and is interested in Japanese Netsuke carvings there is a most wonderful display that has it's own section of the museum. Adjacent to the museum is the oldest synagogue in South Africa.

SA Jewish Museum. I was pleasantly surprised by this museum. The building itself was very modern with clean lines. The museum staff was friendly and very helpful. The exhibits were well done, provided information in an easy to read format and very informative. I would recommend taking the time to go to this museum and visit all 3 floors.

Very Moving. Visited on Wednesday 15/01/2014.This is one of the best museums in Cape Town and the Holacost exhibition so moving all should make it compulsory as part of any trip to Cape Town.
The tribute to the Jewish community by Nelson Mandela in his fight for freedom is superb.
I strongly recommend this two you all

Honouring incredible contributions to South Africa.... The visit to the SA Jewish Museum proved to be insightful and thought provoking. Informative, knowledge sharing displays, including a number of high-tech interactive exhibits. All highlight the history, contributions and suffering of the Jewish in South Africa and across the world. The special Holocaust exhibition was thought-provoking, solemn and spiritual. It certainly reminded me of the atrocities performed against humanity and reinforced the message that it must never happen again!In addition to the actual museum, staff and volunteers at the Centre were most welcoming. All in all, a highly recommended attraction.

So interesting!. The first thing you meet when you enter this museum is the loveliest receptionist who was so welcoming and informative! After that you enter a world of facts, details of peoples lives and information so interesting that you need to walk round slowly to digest it all! It is beautifully laid out and with fascinating artifacts and video clips and interviews. Thoroughly worth a visit. We ate lunch in the cafe which was very nice and had a browse round the shop, which had some lovely African/Jewish pieces.

Maybe we can learn from the museum. A very sad period reflecting the cruelty humans can inflict on each other for misguided philosophies. We, a group from 88 to 16 found something in this well documented history and enjoyed the story as given by those few that relayed it on their journeys to South Africa. Well Done!!By the way admission is free and a visit should be included in your visit to Cape Town

difficult to hear and don't go to the cafe. Located close to the Mount Nelson hotel, this is not just a museum but a community resource.There was a lot of variety in the exhibits - starting from a synagogue and going on to a museum of Jewish settlement in South Africa and life in Cape Town. There is even a mocked up East European stetl, or hamlet.But the insulation of sounds from one exhibit to another wasn't great - so one of the most interesting elements (the role of the Jewish community in the ANC/political struggles and the Rivonia trial) was impossible to hear.Service in the cafe is slow, and the description of food on the menu misleading (for salad read pickled veg) although it may be more meaningful to an Israeli clientele.

Interesting museum. This is a really good stop for anyone interested in the Jewish community in Cape Town. We started with a look at the Shul where we got an idea of the history of the Jews in Cape Town and the building of the Shul. It was a shame we were leaving before Friday night when there was an event on in what seems like a really vibrant community.The museum was interesting and well planned out, including a reconstruction of some buildings in an Eastern European shtetl. The staff were lovely and took time to chat to us. The Holocaust museum was comprehensive and moving. We do always try to get a feel for Jewish communities wherever we are and a museum like this never fails to shock, however many times we learn the history. We were there long after closing time, having been assured by the staff that we could take our time, which showed how sensitive they were to the content and not simply rushing us through. We couldn't fail to notice the frightening similarities between apartheid and the Holocaust, which became a common theme through our trip.

Relaxed and informative. Not necessarily at the top of your initial list when thinking about places to visit in Cape Town, but worth the visit. From an interesting looking a Jewish immigration, a good art gallery, and well put together look at Mandela and his relationship with the Jewish community

A Museum for Everyone. The Museum was built about 3 years ago and is in a complex with a small dairy restaurant that had excellent food, very reasonable prices, there is a place to buy African items, the Holocaust Museum is there, which is visited by the children of Cape Town because there is a direct correlation between the Apartheid era and the Holocaust. Mandela helped raise money for the Jewish Museum because he felt the Jewish community had been instrumental in helping eliminate Apartheid. The Museum itself is beautiful and holds the history of the Jewish people and their contribution to Cape Town. There is a replica of a small village in Eastern Europe which was very interesting to see and an exhibit by a famous artist with the last name of Bak, there as well. Next to the South African Museum is the synagogue that dates back to 1904. It is very beautiful and can hold over 1000 people at one time. The stained glass windows are of the 12 tribes of Israel. If you go to Cape Town, it is a must see. Ricki Bergman, Travel Consultant & World Traveler

Terrific museum and shul next to it. We had a personal tour of the Shul itself which is beautiful with great architecture and recent stain glass windows on the lower portions. we got to meet the Dr. who designed all these recent stain glass windows. Neat. The museum has a lot to show of the Jewish history in Cape Town. The show photos of the dozen or so Shuls which had been in Cape Town over the years. There was an art exhibit by an artist who now lives in the Boston area an dis represented by a Newbury St art Galley. Small world.

Absolutely beautiful museum and well organised set up. This museum is so well thought out, it's modern and entertaining with some ornaments that go way back in history. The fact that you can enter the synagogue next door is wonderful since its 1 of the most beautiful in the world

a new life for europeans. It is an excellent presentation of how Jewish life began in South Africa as Lithuanian Jews followed the Dutch and the Huegenots in search of living space and business opportunities. Unfortunately, there's little to no acknowledgement of how this process of European colonization and immigration displaced the Africans who already lived there.

A Must for ALL to see.... The History of South Africa's Jewish community comes to life, at this museum.I especially enjoyed the multimedia displays,it shares newsreel footage,documentary films & a reconstruction of a 19th century Lithuanian village,quite interesting.The beautiful highlights of this place was its teak pulpit,domed ceiling & stain-glassed windows.

Wow. What an amazing, sensitive and informative place. It is very imformative historically and the model 'Shtetl' very authentic and realistic. One can imagine the type of people and wonderful family life that existed in those times. Conbined with a visit to the adjoining Holocaust Museum it is a must for your Cape Town visit. Sombre, emotional and very informative visiting this place just around the corner from the Mount Nelson Hotel is not a fun experience but it shouldn't be missed.You'll have a better knowledge but a heightened lack of understanding once you've been here.

Moving but beautiful. Beautiful buildings for such a tragic and moving museum. Well worth a visit and a few hours to explore the Jewish story in South Africa. You'll need a couple of hours of you go to both the museum and holocaust memorial .. plus take a break over a coffee. The holocaust museum brought us both to tears ... and we have seen others and not experienced this level of emotion.

Jews of South Africa. This excellent small museum presents the history of The Jewish Community in South Africa. A film on the support the Jewish Community (or at least some in the Jewish Community) gave Nelson Mandela (and his support as president for diversity in SA) plays continuously in a small theatre. Exhibits are informative and give a really intimate sense of this side street of Jewish history. Located on the same "campus" as Africa's only Holocaust Center and the oldest (orthodox ) synagogue in SA as well as a Jewish library with a sales cart for discards, this site is definitely worth a couple of hours in Central Cape Town.

Excellent museum. This is something not to be missed, the museum is very well laid out with a history of the Jewish community in Cape Town, also there is a collection of Japanese carving and Samurai sword components that belonged to one of the founders. There is also a second building housing the Holocuast exhibits. Fascism even reached Cape Town in the 1930's, I don't know why I was surprised but there you are.

Excellent museum, learnt a lot!!. This is a small museum, very well laid out and informative. We had a lovely guide - Joy - who was most knowledgeable & happy to answer our questions, it was a real pleasure to listen to her & hear about the Jewish roots in SA and found it most interesting.

Appealing And Increasing My Knowledge Towards The History. I found the information about this museum when my brother told me about it. He originally got the information from TripAdvisor. We went there together. A little additional information, this building is located near to the Holocaust Museum, and there was also this Jewish / Judaism Shop and the small Cafe near to the museum itself. First we purchased the ticket to the lady at the reception, and then we were told some of the procedures, and also we were told not to take photograph inside. Then we went to the museum. I can see many extraordinary legacy there. First we saw the building with many chairs in the middle (which I guess for praying / gathering), and there were those Jewish / Judaism equipment located around the area. They were really sacred. The museum itself has each of the objects explained really well. It was great to know the history of the Jewish Community from the old times, where they show it on the video display there on the screen and we got to know how the Jewish Community came to South Africa. We then went inside to the inner area, we saw other great things about the Jewish Community, including the other objects inside the museum, and also other great videos that shown us about how The Jewish Wedding were held, how the old leaders had the meeting together, and also other impressive things such as the old buildings and equipment. Finally we went to the upstairs area where we saw all the old photographs and the old texts / letters, and we then went to the restaurant outside the museum while we all had the great knowledge about the History of Jewish Community and also for the old times and what had happened in the past.

Very Good Small Jewish Museum. The Jewish Museum is located in the Garden District next to rhe Great Shul.It is a lovely setting with views of Table Mountain. It contains a small gift shop and cafeteria.The museum deals with the history of Jews in South Africa and the Holocost.It also highligts the major contribution the South African Jews gave in fighting Apartheid .Do not miss the short film on Nelson Mandella pkayed in an adjacent building.

A great overview. This was a really nice, easy to see museum. I found out that Jews came here for the same reasons they came to America, and started out the same way as American Jews did...by being peddlers. Prior to the turn on the 20th c Jews did well in a land without prejudice...and when it came, it hit them and others who didn't write in a "European alphabet." They fought that, just as they fought against apartheid years later. Great overview, and you walk away feeling good.
well worth a visit. Well presented history of south African Jewish life. Some of the exhibits were visual and audio very modern spacious with a good cafeteria and gift shop.
an unknown little treasure. it is a beautiful little temple with incredible and little known history. even if you are not jewish, it is a little jewel of a place and definitely worth visiting

Looking back. I visited the museum out of pure curiosity. I have been to the Smithsonian and wanted to see the differences. The layout of the museum was great and the information from the holocaust to the history of the Jewish community in SA was very informative.
Very educational. Very friendly staff at this museum. Lots of informative information on how the Jewish settlers came to be in South Africa in the early 19th century.

Wonderful Museum. WE had not read about this wonderul museum and only happened upon it as we walked through town. What a great museum not only for those of Jewish heritage but anyone interested in learning about European migration to South Africa. Perhaps we were very fortunate as we got there when no one else was visiting. So we had a private guide - Sam - who explained the museum's contents and the history of the Jewish people in South Africa.
Jewish history. A knowledgeable guide and a good way to understand another aspect of this cultural melting pot.A good shop and cafe as well.
Jewish culture.. A wonderful way to bring you in touch with Jewish culture. The guides are very friendly and informative.
Wow.. It'll leave you with a thought. It'll leave you quiet. Very few places have had such an impact on me. This was one of them.

Fascinating view of history of Capetown. Amazing to see how much the present city owes to the Jews and the biggest surprise was that it was an enlightened Jew who enabled Nelson Mandela to practice law. How different history might have been had it not been for this Jew. Do see the film about Mandela which is available if you ask and then have a wonderful sandwich in the cafe.

Interesting but lacking. Really enjoyed the sections on South Africa and how Jewish people were discriminated against in our past immigration policies and by the Apartheid government. However I would have like more about this. I also think there was a lot of information about the holocaust and WW2 but a lack of reflection about what the world has learnt from this experience.

Sad place. There are a few stirring moments -- a film in which Mandela talks respectfully about the Jewish community is particularly poignant, as are sound bites by Jews discussing their views on apartheid. Downstairs, reached via a fantastic spiral staircase, is a digital repository of Jewish identity and family trees
great place, worth the trip. Really enjoyed this place, a definate if it rains whilst your there, the cafe is ok as well and its close to all the other museums
Moving to say the least. A trip that will stick in your mind forever. Makes one remember how we should live in harmony. A lot of moving stories to tell. Good audio visuals

Beautifully presented. This museum is light and airy yet well laid out with lots of details. Very interesting background to the history of the Jews in South Africa. The Halocaust section is, of course, traumatic but well thought through and presented. Provoking links made with the rise of the Nazis in Germany in the 1930s, (with the consequences), and the parallel Apartheid regime in South Africa up to the 1980s. A must visit if you have a few hours to spend on a rainy day.

Very Nice Museum Worth a Visiting. Jewish immigrants were central to the development and modern history of South Africa. This outstanding museum is a small gem and can be appreciated by all interested in the history of South Africa between the late 19th century and the end of Apartheid. Special treat is the visit to the beautiful 1905 built synagogue also in the grounds.

Excellent venue include the holocaust museum. A beautiful synagogue with a long history in Cape town well worth a visit. Include the Holocaust museum situated right next door. I enjoyed the tour and historical elements of the Jewish population of South Africa

Wonderful portrayl of history. I was pointed to this museum from the hop on hop off bus tour. I'm so glad I went as it's one of the best museum experiences I've ever had. The displays and exhibits were thoughtful, artistic, tasteful and informative; the space is light, airy and welcoming. The docents are very helpful. I learned a lot about the history of Cape Town here as well as from a Jewish perspective. There's also a great tribute to Nelson Mandela. I highly recommend a visit to this small museum. A bonus was I got in for free, maybe because it was Friday or the next day was national museum day in South Africa, not sure.... but that was a nice thing to happen. Go, spend an hour or more, you won't regret it. It's just off the Company Gardens.

A sense of history. I visited the synagogue and the shop to buy a present for a bar mitzvah, but first had a one-on-one guided tour around the synagogue, the architecture is lovely. My guide was extremely interesting and welcomed all the questions I asked about the history and faith of the Jewish people. I intend going back to look around the museum with its unusual construction in the near future.

Jewish History in Cape Town. Modern and well rounded museum giving history and context of Jews in Cape Town. Added highlight was talking to a docent for a half hour. The museum in located next to the National Gallery, also worth seeing, and the Company Gardens, a welcome green strip in the city center.

Interesting and informative. I found this museum fascinating. It is well laid out and gives a really good insight into the contribution the Jews made to South Africa over the years. The staff are enthusiastic and helpful and I was particularly impressed by the adjoining synagogue.

History of Jewish community in South Africa. For those interested in this topic, well worth a visit. The entrance is set in the oldest synagogue in South Africa. Multimedia display of local Jewish History. Be sure also to visit the Holocaust museum, which is adjacent. AFterwards, go for a walk in the Company Gardens.

A good place to visit. Well worth spending half a day here. I found all of the exhibits interesting and well-displayed and came away with a strong sense of the Jewish contribution to South African history (except perhaps the last section on "Dreams"... kind of an anti-climax to the message from the history and survival of the Jewish community in Cape Town). Downstairs a helpful docent explained the marvels of the staircase. Also went to the adjoining Holocaust museum and having been to a few, I still learned something new-- about the Jews of Rhodes especially. Make sure you bring your passport to get in. We ate lunch in the cafe, which was great... I had a really good olive spread/avocado/feta sandwich that I wish I could re-create! Maybe it is a Jewish food.

Good but not great. This museum covers the history of Jews in South Africa as well as a history of Judaism and an overview of the Jewish religion. The museum has a lot of highlights - the reconstruction of an old shtetl from Eastern Europe downstairs is very well done, and the sections on the older history of Jewish immigration to South Africa was very interesting as well. The Holocaust Museum on the same grounds (admission free) was very tasteful and correctly drew parallels and links between apartheid South Africa and Nazism. The short video about Mandela and his relationship with South African Jewry was also very good. The gift shop is also good, as is the cafe.My only complaint is that the museum was not extensive enough. The discussion of the Oppenheimers was incredibly brief and the section on Jews who fought against Apartheid was far too small. There was a little bit about Helen Suzman but nothing at all about Joe Slovo or Lionel 'Rusty' Bernstein except for a brief mention of Slovo on a computer terminal listing prominent South African Jews. I hope this is something that the museum considers altering at some point in the future.
Well worth the visit. This tasteful museum gave us insight into the history of the Cape Town Jewish community. There were interesting exhibits, and there were docents with interesting stories.

Always a pleasure to visit. The museum is housed in a former synagogue and although not much has been added to it since my last visit here two years ago, it’s pleasing to see it being so diligently maintained and carefully looked after. The entrance fee is a modest R40 as at June 2013 (equiv $US4). The museum has its own parking facility, a few metres up the road before you hit the museum coming down Hatfield Road. For more details about it, it’s best to call beforehand because it’s easy to miss it. I did, and ended up parking in the Art Gallery car park a few metres past the museum although that wasn’t too much of a drama as it’s nearby and you just throw the parking attendant a few coins when you leave.This being a Jewish facility and in crime-ridden South Africa to boot it’s understandable that security is tight. So it’s wise to have some ID with you (such as passport or driver’s licence) and be prepared for a bag search and a few questions. But it won’t hold you up more than a couple of minutes and I always find the guards to be polite and businesslike. They even helped with directions to my next destination on my way out.Once inside, take your time to meander around and enjoy all the exhibits that trace the history of this vibrant, loyal and productive community from its earliest days in the Cape Colony at the start of the 19th century, through to mass immigration that swelled the Jewish population to over 40,000 between about 1890 and 1936, when restrictions were placed on further immigration by a pro-German white govt. At its peak, the Jewish community of SA numbered about 120,000 and at one time comprised almost 5% of the white population. There is also a strong focus on the involvement of the community in the anti-apartheid movement. Nelson Mandela’s first employers in Johannesburg were Jewish and he never forgot that, maintaining a strong affinity and respect for the Jewish community throughout his career. And it was he who officially opened the museum in 2000.There is an interesting exhibition downstairs of ancient Japanese miniature artwork, collected by a prominent Jewish South African and donated to the museum. Plus a photo exhibition by Paul Weinberg, recording his travels through the countryside where his forebears once lived and had businesses.I was excited to find a book listing all the Jewish émigrés who arrived at the Cape Colony between 1890 and 1905. There is a second volume of arrivals between 1905 and 1936.Don’t forget to visit the little shop afterwards which has a small but interesting collection of books and other knick knacks and of course Café Riteve for a sandwich and coffee. The staff are friendly, helpful and welcoming to all visitors. Being a Jewish ex-Capetonian, I always find this museum a joy to visit. It’s a moving experience that can bring a tear to your eye. It isn’t large and you should be able to cover it in about two hours.

The story of Jews in SA beautifully presented. This is a moderate-sized and very approachable museum which tells the story of Jews in SA in a graphical way. A bonus is a comprehensive listing of steamship arrivals of Jewish immigrants in the early 20th century. The museum also tells the story of SA's development in the 19th and 20th century with emphasis on the role of the Jewish community. The museum is conveniently located in "Museum Row" and is in a tranquil courtyard which includes the old synagogue and Holocaust Museum

Never Again. I loved everything about this museum, it is has a very simple layout, but it is full of so much information and history. You have to brace yourself when you go into the Holocaust Centre though, it's a very intense experience.
Educational. Had a great guide, Sheila. Gave lots of information. Museum very informative of immigration of Jews in South Africa and their role in the development of South African society

Interesting, see for yourself. I enjoyed the Jewish Museum, the library boast a big collection of interesting artefacts. If you have an interesting in Jewish history I highly recommend you visit, however, there are defiantly other interesting museums that I think is worth a view too. So it is important you decide early which ones you would prefer to spend your money on.

A Friday Visit To South African Jewish Museum. It was Friday and the museum closes at 2pm in advance of Shabbat. My tour ended at 12:30 and the guide (a native of Cape Town) was kind enough to drop me there. He had visited it and knew where it was.I had 50 minutes and a wonderful docent gave me a private tour of the synagogue and museum. He was extremely knowledgeable about the exhibits, the design and architecture of the museum and the history of the Jewish community in South Africa. He proudly showed me the special exhibit of netsuke figures and explained the history to me. There is also a lovely restaurant/cafe to grab lunch.

A Gem!. Only had a very short amount of time to see the Jewish Museum, but since my great-grandfather and some distant parts of my family emigrated here in the late 1800's, I was intrigued. They also had an exhibit on Jewish influence in District 6 in Cape Town.
Even if you are not Jewish, go.... It was well worth the time. A few minutes after I entered, a volunteer started to give me a private tour.

Interesting but not a must. Made the mistake on going initially on a Jewish holiday so was closed but managed to pop in the next day. Infiormative but a little repetative by the time you get to the end.

JEWISH MUSEUM, CAPE TOWN. Don't miss the Holocaust exhibition. The whole museum is really interesting. There is a good coffee shop which also serves light meals and it has its own parking area adjacent. Situated alongside th national Iziko museum and Planetarium.

Worth a visit. This is well worth a visit, not just because of the Jewish history, or the holocaust story but because they have possibly the best short film about Nelson Mandela. The restaurant looks really nice, but I didn't have time to stay.

A hidden treasure. Although not that well publicised, this museum and exhibition was well worth while. The displays are very well done and very informative. We all need to be more aware of the dark past.

South African Jewish history very interesting. The City Sightseeing Tour bus dropped us off quite near here. Very interesting history of the Jews in South Africa. We had a wonderful guide (he said he was a nice Jewish boy from Johannesburg) who went out of his way to give us a personalized tour. Time well spent.
very moving. Very interesting, very moving, compares well to a big city museum. Is worth the trip and not just for a rainy day

worth a visit. Always a haunting experience visiting a Holocaust Museum. But something we must always be reminded of. Very well displayed. Of course I cried a lot, which always happens when I visit a Holocaust museum. It was also interesting seeing the Jewish Museum and a very beautiful synagogue. We went from there straight to the Company Gardens and the Iziko National Art Museum.

Very Interesting and Informative. I had a stroll through the Company's Gardens and then decided to visit the South African Jewish Museum. On arrival I was greeted by friendly staff and taken on tour by Rod. Very informative and interesting tour where I learned a lot about the Jewish religion and culture. The museum is worth a visit and I will be back again to explore all the exhibits!

Very interesting museum with friendly staff. We visited the jewish Museum on a Friday because we spent the day in town because it rained. The Museum is quite new and has interesting exhibitions, we saw 6th district Exhibition and one about Little miniature japanese figures (forgot the Name of them) A very friendly man showed us around and gave us a lot of Details about the history. we also went to the Holocaust centre which was sad but alerting and although they were about to Close we could go in.

A revelation!. I had the privilege of having a tasty lunch with friends at the restaurant adjoining the Jewish Museum and then visited the museum. The history of the Jewish population of Europe is extremely well illustrated, down to the actual Shekel built inside the museum. The horror of the holocaust is also so well depicted that one cannot help but feel the desperation and terror which so many thousands had to endure. It is a must to visit as it broadens one's understanding of persecution and hardship!

A storied community. Going back over 150 years, Jews were an integral part of the history of Cape Town, and South Africa.This museum and the holocaust museum next door, sit on the perimeter of the "Gardens" the Central Park of Cape Town. All the most important buildings ie. Senate, Parliament and Presidents House.. as well as the National Museum and the Art Museum amongst others... The beautifully maintained park, gardens are a pleasant and peaceful place to walk through and relax in the center of the City.

A must see. The S.A Jewish Museum is a must see. It depicts the history of the Jewish people of South Africa and how they came to be here and what they contributed to S. africa.THey often have exhibits. At the moment the exhibit is on the "Jews of District 6" which is very interesting. It is really worthwhile and alongside it is the Holocause Museum which is also an absolute must see

Very interesting and just the right size. I knew nothing about South African Jews and found this museum to be a real eye opener. There was an exhibition about the Jews of District 6 which was very enlightening. And I loved how it's not a gigantic place where you get lost for hours.

A Jewish Place of Worship and History. The old synagogue is used as a museum describing present Jewish life and history. There is a small exhibit of old religious articles that survived the times. Downstairs there are replicas of houses in the ghetto and life size pictures of ghetto life. The atmosphere is informational, factual and non-emotional.There also is a non-related collection of Japanese miniatures, netsukes.The new synagogue consists of a large prayer hall and has an architecturally pleasing interior. Prayer services are conducted at a very regular times.There also is a nice kosher restaurant on the premises, where you can meet people from all over the world, sometimes even people you know.

I LEARNT AN AWFULL LOT. Centrally located to the side of the "Companies Gardens" in down town Cape Town the Jewish museum is easy to find and has plenty of car parking for a city centre venue. My advice is just go and make your own mind up. But GO!
Fascinating. This stylish, friendly museum details the history of Jews in S Africa, and their contributions to the development of the country in business, the Arts, politics. Plus a welcome cafe!
modern, well layed out museum. Good use of modern technology and description of Judaism and also of the treatment of Jews during World War 2

Outstanding Exhibits. Although the District 6 museum encouraged me to visit this museum, I found not only a new perspective, from a Jewish point of view but also a fantastic exhibit on Japanese netsukes. Recreating the small houses, the set table and artifacts used by this community illuminated and extended the information from the District 6 Museum. Photographs also helped explain the repressive times.We also visited the synagogue. We were so glad we had visited this museum although it had not been on our original itinerary. We highly recommend it and wished we had had more time to examine the other collections here.
Special Place. Good, hearty Jewish food and excellent atmosphere. The perfect place to go for refreshment after visiting the Jewish Museum or Holocaust Center

Well laid out. The whole experience was fantastic! the other museums in Cape Town can take a leaf out of this book! it is well laid out and flows! the staff are friendly and attentive and you never feel like you are just another visitor!

Fantastic Museum. I very much enjoyed visiting this museum, which was incredibly informative about the Jewish population's migration to South Africa starting early in the 19th century. The museum also highlights the contributions of ordinary and prominent Jews even today. We had a wonderful guide, Sam, volunteer to show us around the museum. Beginning with one of the oldest synagogue in SAfrica and finishing with a very well done Shtetel replica, I thought the museum was incredibly informative and very interesting. The Holocaust Museum (entrance free) is across the street and also worth a visit. Highly recommend.

Excellent memorial. This is a stop on the Hop On-Hop Off bus tour. We were impressed with the information presented both about the Holocaust and the Jewish connection/support for the abolishment of apartheid.There is a cafe which also serves great coffee and cake too.

Worth a visit if you have time to spare. Lots of information but much is what most people already know except for the information on Jewish immigration to South Africa.We spent almost 3 hours there as there was lots to see but if it had not been a cool Sunday when most other sites were closed I think an hour for a quick overview would have been enough

One of the Best Jewish Museums Anywhere. Don't Miss It!. This was a great museum that I would highly recommend whether you're Jewish or not. Very modern with awesome displays and exhibits. Interesting history of the Jewish community in South Africa. I had no idea that Nelson Mandela had so much involvement with the Jewish Community there. Also, there was a wonderful exhibit on "District Six" which was a melting pot in the heart of Cape Town for many, many years until it was bulldozed bythe local government and its inhabitants forced to move. The exhibit at the Jewish Museum was so much more informative and well documented than the District Six museum itself! It really explained what that areas was like. There is also a lovely gift shop and cafe. The docents at this museum are so helpful and informative as well all adding to the knowledge and insight you can get out of your time. This is a "don't miss" while in Cape Town!

History of South African Jews. We visited this museum and spent a few hours learning about the history of the Jews of Cape Town. The museum is high tech and interactive. There is a film about Nelson Mandela. The Gardens Synagogue is attached to the museum and our group attended the Friday night services. It was a beautiful service and there is a wonderul men's choir. Please note that if you want to attend services, you must arrange this in advance and be prepared to to show your passport.

Easy to get to with great historical value. So much has been handed into the museum from Cape Townians who had the items in their family. Brings it home to one. Its a museum that everyone should see. Its also beautifully laid out

Litvak life in SA. Very interesting for anyone who has an interest in the history of the Jews in South Africa. The main section of the museum documents the life of the Litvaks before the left Lithuania, and after they arrived in South Africa.A special exhibition is on at the moment on life in in District Six, which was flattened during the apartheid experiment. An excellent kosher cafe is attached, and good book shop selling Judaica and other items relating to the exhibitions.

Lovely, informative, interesting complex--much to offer. The South Africa Jewish Museum is part of a complex including the lovely 1863 synagogue which is the entrance to the musem (the first synagogue built in South Africa), as well a the Gardens Shul, the magnificent 1905 synagogue right next door which is still in use. The free Cape Town Holocaust Center is part of the complex and should not be missed. There is also a cafe and gift shop. Entrance fee is a reasonable 40 Rand (about $4.50). The museum is in the Company's Garden area.of Cape Town. This modern, informative museum was opened in 2000 by Nelson Mandela and tells the story of Jews in South Africa. There was terrific exhibits, videos, interactive media and pictures. The is a full scale model of an old Eastern European shtetl which you can tour and presently, an exhibit on District 6, an area that housed Jews, as well as blacks, Asians, etc. in the early part of the century and was torn down during the apartheid era--very moving. Do not miss this wonderful complex (note--we needed picture identification before entering the complex). Be aware that the museum is only open until 2 PM on Friday and is closed on Saturday. It is open the other days of the week.

Heart wrenching. I visited the holocaust museum and found it to be not only informative but also very emotional. As I left I could not hold back the tears. I'm not Jewish so knew very little about what happened. To watch interviews with survivors was heart wrenching. I would suggest locals pay this centre a visit.
Since I visited Yad Vashem in Israel, I´m not in awe, but.... Since I visited Yad Vashem in Israel, I´m not in awe, but it is a small and nice museum, with very good taste. I recommend.
Very Informative. A surprisingly good holocaust and Jewish history muesem. Exhibits highlighting the experiences of survivors who moved to South Africa were very good. The museum cafe is excellent.

Amazing museum, Fantastic Mandela film. This museum was very well done and easy to walk around and learn from--with the exception of some videos that were hard to see (the way the light hit the screens) and hear (a lot of ambient noise got in the the way). Still the fantastic number of photos and memorabilia and easy to read quotes and captions made this a top place to visit. We found the District 6 information to be easier to read and access than in the actual District 6 Museum, where it seemed to be wall to wall newspaper selections and hard to decide what to read. Next to this museum is the Holocaust museum, also a VERY well done history--concise and thorough. I learned more here than at the US Holocaust museum, maybe because it was so concise. We were told 30 minutes in the Holocaust museum (perfect for my friends--I took about 40 minutes) and about an hour in the Jewish Museum. BUt BE SURE to leave time for the 27 minute film interview with Mandela which covered Jewish history intertwined with ANC and anti-apartheid activities. An excellent movie, not available elsewhere. Easy to hear and see as it's in a small auditorium. Again, we learned more here than at the District 6 museum and Bo Kapp museum together (though both are definitely worth visiting).

Very informative museum almost spoilt by security. Excellent museum with great displays, making great use of technology and lighting to create immersive experience. Also does a great job of showing the relevance of the subject matter to South Africa - which might not be very clear at first. Full marks for the great museum, you'll enjoy it if you get in.Which isn't as easy as it sounds. Security standards are typically Israeli, you need to have your passports on, be patted down and go through metal detectors... Which would all be bearable if the security was not so rude!

Helpfull. We never realised that also in South Africa, the jewisch were not welcome. The film regarding Nelson Mandela we have seen. We understood in his younger years Nelson was a kind of terrorist in SA.
Excellent Cultural experience. This tour carried out by Sheila, a very experienced guide, was most informative and enjoyable. Certainly a must on any educational tour.
Proof of identity. We didn't have our passports on us so were refused entrance by a very rude security guard. I'd give it a miss.

Wonderful museum. Small, but excellent museum. Well worth a visit to learn about the history of Jews in Cape Town. There is also a small holocaust museum next door, which is included with your admission ticket. I wish I had more time to visit the holocaust museum, as it seemed excellent too from my brief walk through. Note that the hop-on hop-off bus stops right by the museum for convenient access.
Very Moving. A most thought provoking experience. Mans inhumanity to man is quite beyond comprehension. Every child should visit with their parents. We must never forget.

Well worth a visit.... Went to the Jewish museum sometime last year and wasn't really sure what to expect but after the visit I was very glad that I had gone. First of all there is a disabled parking bay but it took some navigating to get past the drums which are there I suppose to deter others. Getting past the drums took some elbow grease from the security guard and my friend as the drum had to be moved so I could get out but from there it’s easy access all the way.You start in the old Synagogue, which for me is just beautiful; I love the "old" feel which one gets at certain places. And from there you go through the exhibition section, on the lower level which is accessed either via a stunning staircase or a lift you enter the old village (I think it’s called a shtetl), the detail is brilliant... Back up in the lift and there is another lift close to the coffee shop which will take you to the Cape Town Holocaust Centre. It was quite an emotional visit.We ended off our visit with a cup of tea at Café Riteve (if I remember correctly).

Very educational and worthwhile visit. A few blocks from the Green Market Square area of Cape Town, the museum is not more than a 10 minute drive from the Waterfront area (about R40.00 or $5.00). Security is tight so expect your bags to be searched as you sign in at the front gate. As you do the self-guided tour of the museum, there are many artifacts to look at as well as many storyboards and videos showing a history of the Jewish people in Cape Town. There was so much to read and see, our 1 1/2 hours there flew by. Unfortunately, time did not allow for us to tour the holocaust museum but we did have a few minutes to check out the small gift shop where I bought a beautiful metal art piece at a reasonable price hand made in Cape town. A cafe in the same building had snacks and drinks which my mom enjoyed. My only regret is that we ran out of time as the museum closes promptly at 5:00pm. To do this museum right, please allow at least 2-3 hours. We decided to walk back to the V & A Waterfront which turned out to be a nice walk, all downhill, and took us about 45 minutes. Don't do this walk after dark as once the business district closes down, it is unwise to stroll the streets in this area.

Best Museum I visited in the 4 weeks in the Cape. The museum was closed for refurbishment when I arrived in Cape Town at the end of July but open when I was back in late August. Very well laid out with good graphics, visuals and audio telling the story of the Jews in the Cape and the experience of European Jews in the 1939-1945 holocaust. Many survivors made their way to South Africa so there is plenty of personal testimony.I spent 4 hours in the museum which is some testimony to its interest. After 4 weeks along the western Cape and Garden Route, this was the best museum I visited

Well Curated. A well curated look at the history of Jewish immigrants in South Africa along with some basic information about Judaism. It also includes a collect of Japaneses Miniatures and a wonderfully designed staircase. Honestly the staircase is notably pleasant.
Moving. Beautiful old shul, great little kosher restaurant, with a great little gift shop, a holocaust museum which connects to apartheid, and a Jewish library

A big complex. To call this place “just” a museum is doing it an injustice. The South African Jewish Museum sits opposite the Holocaust Museum, and the Great Synagogue sits behind them. There is a clear progression through the museums and the displays are informative.  While it will certainly be interesting and relevant to Jewish people, including a very extensive history of Jews in South Africa, there is enough there for everyone to enjoy. Worth a look.

A must-see if you're Jewish and interesting even if you're not. Due to time, we didn't get to see everything in this museum but it's very new and the exhibits are state-of-the-art. The South African Jewish community has a long and fascinating history and the museum is well worth exploring. The shop is a must also! I was above to find all kinds of one-of-a-kind items like wire and bead menorahs shaped like various African animals--a unique souvenir of my trip that I couldn't have found anywhere else.

A interesting experience. We walked up through Company Gardens,and find the SA Jewish Museum next next to the Gallery on the left . The entrance however is in Hatfield Street, with no obvious access from the Gardens. However, there is a dirt road pedestrians can cut across, just past the museum, which takes you out onto Hatfield Street. The Museum, Synagogue and shop/cafe is set in a compound, and you will need personal ID to get through the security, sign a logbook, and enter the compound. The first impression is that the compound is extremely clean, tidy and well kept. There was a very helpful friendly lady who took us into the synagogue, and, not being of the Jewish faith, spent some time explaining the set up and working of the synagogue. She was a gem, and we learnt a lot.The museum is part of the first synagogue built Cape Town. It is well laid out, and worth a visit, telling the story of where the community came from and how they integrated into the South African culture.We had lunch at the cafe before visiting the holocaust museum. It is interesting but at the same time also shocking and left you with a sad feeling and ashamed at what humans(nations) can do when they believe they are right. Also so amazing to realize that with the help of God a nation was saved again although so many had to suffer and die as a result.
Very memorable experience. I visited the museum with a group some 3 years ago and it was a very moving experience. Can definately recommend. Take tissues! I was very emotional.

Amazing Museum. Any country I travel to I visit the Jewish areas and museums if they have one. I thought the South African Jewish Museum and Holocaust Centre was outstanding. We spent 6 hours touring both areas plus had lunch in the lovely cafe on campus. Don't miss these wonderful museums whether you are Jewish or not. Both are filled with lots of history, art, and interesting exhibits. The connection of the Jewish people with Apartheid was something I didn't know before along with the struggle the Black, Color and Jewish people of South Africa shared. A museum not to be missed!

A must for all the history lovers. Use the hop on hop off bus to visit this very interesting museum with the Holocaust Centre also on the premises. Remember to bring your ID book to enter this museum. The history of the Jews in South Africa was also very interesting
slice of jewish life in SA. interesting history & museum is next to Holocaust Museum. We should never forget

Amazing presentation, difficult topic. We went to see both the Jewish Museum and the Holocaust Centre, which is located in the same complex.To enter, you must clear a security gate, requiring some form of ID.Entrance into the Jewish Museum was 40R and the holocaust was free (but we left a donation).The information in the Jewish museum was outstanding, with information from many years ago, leading up to Jewish settlement in Capetown and other businesses involved in the area.We really enjoyed it.After about 2 hours in the museum, we exalted over to the holocaust centre and spent another 2 hours. easy to do as there is plenty of information both written and audio. It was very detailed and presented in a fabulous way. As a teacher, I was very pleased to be able to buy some educational resources too.We highly recommend this museum combination, but we were quite emotionally exhausted afterwards.
Eye Opening. I went away from here having learnt something: Jews were instrumental in the struggle against apartheid. I got a bit teary-eyed here and now have an even deeper respect for Jews.
A most entralling experience. The Saff were really helpfull the exhibits wel;l laid out and linked. All together a most entralling experience for me as a non Jew.

Holocaust Centre. Accessible walk-through self-explanatory layout with audio-visual components. The serious subject matter is respectfully presented and placed in a South African context where applicable.The personal testimony video near the exit affected us deeply.
Lots to see. get the perspective of the Jewish Community from Cape Town. Probably on a par with out Jewish Museums around the world.
Sad but Informative and worth a visit!. The holocaust museum, in particular, is worth the investment of an hour or so as it's informative and enlightening.

Interesting - remember your ID/passport, though. The Jewish museum and Holocaust museum are set in a secure compound just off the Company's Gardens, but access is round the other side, on Hatfield Street. It's a bit of a strange experience entering the museum, as unlike the others, you have to present your ID or passport first, which will be checked and noted, before you pass through a turnstile into the compound. It is slightly off-putting, but I imagine there are sound reasons for the tight security. Don't let it put you off going though - non-Jewish people are very welcome to visit and once inside, I was made to feel extremely welcome. Initially I looked at the working synagogue, interesting if you not familiar with the layout and quite old, end of the 19th century I believe. Then I went into the museum proper, which starts off in the very first synagogue which opened in SA and has displays explaining some of the tenets and practices of the Jewish faith. Further along there are displays explaning the history of Jewish immigration to SA, political issues, prominent South African Jews, and other material.Downstairs there is a reconstruction of a Lithuanian shtetl - a small wooden village, as apparently most SA Jews came originally from Lithuania. It's quite atmospheric and you can wander around. Finally there is a temporary exhibition space.I didn't visit the Holocaust museum, but that is on the same site along with a gift shop and a kosher cafe. Generally I found it all interesting although I wouldn't say it was the best museum I've ever been to. Anyone who has particular interests in Judaism should obviously take a look and it's a good eye-opening experience for non-Jews.
Chilling. An emotional and wothwhile expereince - can use the hop on hop off bus that stops infromt of the Museum

Have your hankies ready.. Brutality is never nice to see, this place will remind you of that.
Also enjoy a good lunch at the milchic restaurant.

Dont forget to take some ID with you. We had spent the morning walking up through Company Gardens, and having just finished at the Art Gallery, decided to follow the Rough Guide Book and go to the SA Jewish Museum next, which is next to the Gallery on the left as you walk up Company Gardens. The entrance however is in Hatfield Street, with no obvious access from the Gardens. However, there is a carpark pedestrians can cut across, between the two buildings, which takes you out onto Hatfield Street. The Museum, Synagogue and shop/cafe is set in a compound, and you will need personal ID to get through the security, sign a logbook, and enter the compound. The first impression is that the compound is extremely clean, tidy and well kept. There was a very helpful lady who took us into the synagogue, and, not being of the Jewish faith, spent some time explaining the set up and working of the synagogue. She was a gem, and we learnt a lot.The museum is well laid out, and worth a visit, telling the story of where the community came from and how they integrated into the South African culture.

Great portrait of Jewish South African heritage. Really nice little museum that does a great job showcasing the history of the Jewish population in South Africa. There's also a very well done Holocaust museum attached.

Good historical place to go.. This museum was well organized and very interesting. Jewish history in South Africa is short (first synagogue built in 1860's), but this museum put all the information suscinctly. The location (the original synagogue) is beautiful, the displays well done. And there was a temporary exhibit of Zapiro's political cartoons about Mandela that was fabulous: go before that leaves at the end of January '12.

A hidden heritage gem in Cape Town. I never realised the impact this community has had on SA untill I visited this museum. It give a very interesting overview of the background of the South African Jewish community with their roots in Eastern Europe. There is also a section on the Second World War and the horror suffered by this community in Europe. I found the museum well kept and interesting in the manner the displays were arranged. while also informative.

impressive. This museum is well funded, you can see it. Great, informative, interesting displays showcasing the history of jewish families and their involvement in the development of the country as well as in many cases, their huge contribution. They often have temporary art and photography exhibitions as well, all of which has always been impressive. This museum is one of my favourite and well worth a visit. I return regularly and am never disappointed.

Zapiro exhibition is not to be missed!. We enjoyed very much Zaprio's "Jiving with Mandiba" exhibition. A large and well organised presentation of cartoons by Jonathan Schapiro, who ought to be listed as a living national treasure of South Africa (though the current political powers-that-be might not agree...). For anyone with even a passing interest in wanting to understand South African politics post 1994, this is a must. Do not pass through Cape Town without visiting this exhibition!

A Wonderful compact Museum. This museum is one of the stops on the Cape Town Hop On/Off tour bus although we walked there from the city centre and caught the bus afterwards.A discount for entry is given to holders of the hop on/off ticket.It is quite a hard museum to find owing to the fact that it has a security entry and in a fully fenced compound.We think there is only one entry point and they screen everyone coming into the grounds here.Security personnel are thorough but friendly and you must sign in and out and go through a small portal.This didn't worry us in the least as they are only doing their job.The grounds are lovely and the old synagogue is a white building with an entry near the park to see the rest of the museum. We did not see another entry point (if they have one.)Here you pay the 50 Rand entry (full price) and photos are allowed of all the beautiful ceremonial items on display with explanations of their use in Judaism ritual.Cameras and movie cameras must be turned off after that part of the museum.The old Synagogue architecture is lovely and an interesting presentation of Nelson Mandela and the story of the Jewish struggle and life in South Africa is on an upper level.Walking down the unusual winding ramp you have another very good exhibition of 'the Shtetl ', a look in the life of an eastern European Jewish village.... wonderful!Also along the downstairs walls are many photographs and art, most of which relates to the struggle during Apartheid. Restrooms are here at this level.The holocaust memorial and information is in another building however we did not have time to visit.A modern cafe and gift shop are located in the grounds and although food is limited to a small choice, it is still very good.The gift shop sells a variety of items, including Judaica, South African items and books.We found this museum outstanding. It is a comprehensive and factual insight into Judaism in South Africa as well as a look into the struggle for independence.Enjoy your visit!

Fabulous museum for all history lovers. My husband and I spent a morning at the museum and were very impressed. We loved it! The museum is very new, modern, high-tech and well laid out. I got caught up learning about all the different, interesting people who lived there including a man who made a fortune in ostrich feathers - until they were no longer the fashionable thing for women to wear on hats! I had also wanted to find out how the Jews had reacted to apartheid and was not disappointed. The recreated village made me start humming songs from "Fiddler On the Roof!" We enjoyed the gift shop as well.
